comment._content:
As a member of the Royal Horse Guards, "Sgt" Oakley's rank is "Corporal of Horse".

The Household Cavalry does not use the rank title of Sergeant at all and all NCOs wear a crown above their stripes.

During World War 1 there were three regiments in the Household Cavalry, the 1st Life Guards, the 2nd Life Guards and the Royal Horse Guards.

The 1st Life Guards and the 2nd Life Guards amalgamated into The Life Guards in 1928.

The Royal Horse Guards amalgamated with the 1st (Royal) Dragoons in 1969 to become the Blues & Royals.

comment._content:
I am, again, grateful to Mr Graham Sacker at the Machine Gun Corps database who looked to see if there was any record of a CoH J Oakley on his files, as on 10th May 1918 the RHG temporarily converted to machine-gunners, as 3rd Battalion (RHG) Guards Machine Gun Regiment, (3 GMGR).

The Machine Gun Corps database does not include full research records of the GMGR, but he suggested that this might be "... 4067 Edward James Oakley, GMGR, whose Silver War Badge card is online, showing an enlistment date 12/11/1914 - discharge 23/12/1918 under KR 392 (xvia). Sadly there are no papers for him in the "burned Records" (WO363), but there probably are within RHQ of the RHG."//

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
Despite extensive investigation, CoH Oakley remains something of an enigma.  He does not appear to have a Medal Card on the National Archive database that is unequivocally identifiable as him - from which it is reasonable to draw the conclusion that he perhaps did not deploy overseas on active service during the war.  His uniform appears pristine and shows no evidence of the rigours of campaign service.  There is something about him that suggests that he is a 'Regular' soldier.

The photograph was taken at the Hyde Park studio of Henry Walter Barnett, the society photographer who specialised in portraits, which further suggests that CoH Oakley was based in London.  The depot and remount training centre of the Royal Horse Guards 1896-1969 was at Albany Street Barracks, Regent's Park.  A substantial training and horse-keeping staff would have been required there - so perhaps, having previously been an experienced horseman, that was where he was most effective and employed.//
